unnormalised: Mumbai, India – Ongoing logistics bottlenecks continue to hamper India's manufacturing and supply chain operations, impacting businesses nationwide. A recent report from the Indian Institute of Foreign Trade (IIFT) indicates that delays at ports and inland transportation are significantly increasing production costs.
normalised: Mumbai, India – Ongoing logistics bottlenecks continue to hamper India's manufacturing and supply chain operations, impacting businesses nationwide. A recent report from the Indian Institute of Foreign Trade (I I F T) indicates that delays at ports and inland transportation are significantly increasing production costs.

unnormalised: Manufacturers in sectors ranging from textiles in Tiruppur to automotive components in Pune are reporting disruptions. Trucking shortages, exacerbated by the festive season rush around Diwali, have led to delivery backlogs of up to 2 weeks in some regions.
normalised: Manufacturers in sectors ranging from textiles in Tiruppur to automotive components in Pune are reporting disruptions. Trucking shortages, exacerbated by the festive season rush around Diwali, have led to delivery backlogs of up to two weeks in some regions.

unnormalised: The Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) has urged the government to expedite infrastructure projects, specifically upgrading port facilities and expanding railway networks.
normalised: The Confederation of Indian Industry (C I I) has urged the government to expedite infrastructure projects, specifically upgrading port facilities and expanding railway networks.

unnormalised: "The situation is becoming a 'Deewar' – an insurmountable barrier – to our growth aspirations," commented Mr. Rajesh Sharma, CEO of a Delhi-based electronics manufacturer, referencing the classic Bollywood film. He further stated that the delays are affecting his company’s ability to meet export orders, potentially impacting revenue by Rs. 20 crore this quarter. Improving road connectivity by constructing more expressways and reducing transit times by optimizing routes for lorries travelling distances like the Mumbai-Delhi route (~1400 km) are crucial for sustainable growth.
